sols_html:
Using truth tables.

We write the truth table for each of the two statements that we would like to compare.

[c]@lllll@ P & Q & R & Q \(\vee\) R & P \(\rightarrow\) (Q \(\vee\) R)

T & T & T & T & T
T & T & F & T & T
T & F & T & T & T
T & F & F & F & F
F & T & T & T & T
F & T & F & T & T
F & F & T & T & T
F & F & F & F & T

And

[c]@llllll@ P & Q & R & P \(\rightarrow\) Q & P \(\rightarrow\) R & (P \(\rightarrow\) Q) \(\vee\) (P \(\rightarrow\) R)

T & T & T & T & T & T
T & T & F & T & F & T
T & F & T & F & T & T
T & F & F & F & F & F
F & T & T & T & T & T
F & T & F & T & T & T
F & F & T & T & T & T
F & F & F & T & T & T

Since the last column is the same for both tables (and since we order the truth of \(P\), \(Q\) and \(R\) in the same order) we can conclude that the two statements are logically equivalent.

Another solution consists of using an equivalent statement for the implication:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A \Rightarrow B \equiv \lnot A \lor B\end{aligned}\]

So the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle P \Rightarrow ( Q \lor R ) \equiv ( P \Rightarrow Q ) \lor ( P \Rightarrow R)\end{aligned}\]

becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lnot P \lor ( Q \lor R )) \equiv ( \lnot P \lor Q ) \lor ( \lnot P \lor R)\end{aligned}\]

To prove this statement, we’ll just show that the left hand side (LHS) is equal to the right hand side (RHS).

For the LHS, we get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lnot P \lor ( Q \lor R )) \equiv \lnot P \lor Q \lor R\end{aligned}\]

since disjunction (the logical OR) is associative (that means doesn’t care about brackets).

For the RHS we get

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle ( \lnot P \lor Q ) \lor ( \lnot P \lor R) \equiv \lnot P \lor Q \lor R\end{aligned}\]

since again the disjunction is associative and having twice the \(\neg\)P term is useless.

We obtained that LHS = RHS which proves the statement.
